thread.title: Syrian Civilians Suffer Attacks on Retreat From the Regime

author: Raja Abdulrahim
title: Syrian Civilians Suffer Attacks on Retreat From the Regime
text:
1 COMMENTS Thousands of Syrians desperate to escape the regime’s grip on a battered rebel-held Damascus suburb are being taken on arduous bus rides to the last major opposition bastions in the north, at times braving attacks by regime loyalists.
Those making the trip of around 200 miles—including women, children and armed rebels—have crossed through multiple government checkpoints and at times been stopped and searched. Buses have passed slowly through pro-government towns, with signs of President Bashar al-Assad’s victory over the rebels on full display. 
Regime loyalists have thrown stones at them, breaking bus windows. Some traveled nearly a day without food.
These evacuations are the result of deals reached with the government earlier this month, but officials have made the passage difficult.
“The whole way the regime was terrorizing the buses,” said Anas al-Khole, who left the besieged rebel enclave of Eastern Ghouta on Wednesday night for the northwestern Idlib province. “They tried to make the trip as long as possible.”
The drivers were under orders to restrict passengers from getting off at any point on the nearly nine-hour journey, Mr. Khole said. “Some children had to relieve themselves on the bus.”
Syrian and Russian soldiers inspect the belongings of rebels and their families who being evacuating from Eastern Ghouta. Photo: Ammar Safarjalani/Zuma Press The convoy of some 50 buses drove slowly—never exceeding 25 miles an hour—as it passed through government-controlled territory, where tanks and armored vehicles were parked at the entrance of every town, Mr. Khole said.
For the regime, such public parades of defeated rebels and civilians are an important part of the narrative that it is emerging victorious against foreign-backed terrorists after seven years of conflict .
Buses have been leaving Ghouta’s towns every day for the past week, since evacuations first began under deals reached between rebel groups and the regime.
Despite the challenges, scores of civilians on Friday prepared to leave the last rebel enclave near Damascus as part of those surrender deals. More than 128,000 people have left Ghouta, according to Syrian state media.
Forces loyal to Mr. Assad, backed by Russia and Iran, have carried out a ground and air assault since February that has killed nearly 2,000 people, according to local figures. The offensive was launched after a five-year siege that caused widespread malnutrition and dozens of deaths from lack of medical care.
A man looking at his family for the last time after they were approved to leave Eastern Ghouta. Photo: Muhmmad Al-Najjar/Zuma Press The regime now controls most of Ghouta, and negotiations on some form of deal for the city of Douma, one of the last major rebel-held towns there, are under way, according to residents waiting to leave.
A complete victory over Ghouta would further consolidate regime control around the capital and could pave the way for assaults on the remaining opposition-held areas in the country.
The Syrian regime has said the assault on Ghouta is part of a counterterrorism operation to root out terrorists “who reject the national reconciliation,” according to state media. Mr. Assad has vowed to retake every inch of Syria.
The United Nations says that about 80,000 people have evacuated Ghouta to the shelters around Damascus but it isn’t tracking how many are choosing to go to northern Syrian areas still under rebel control, such as Idlib.

Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs in Damascus.
The evacuations from Ghouta have been characterized by uncertainty and chaos—days of waiting followed by scrambles to board.
“Families left Eastern Ghouta quickly and did not know where they would go,” the International Committee of the Red Cross reported this week. “In such a chaotic situation, many family members were separated, including children from their parents.”
Photos taken in towns and villages waiting to be emptied and posted by activists online showed long lines of dusty and bedraggled people carrying children and dragging suitcases and potatoes sacks packed with clothes and other possessions.
“We waited in line for the buses for about eight hours until we were able to board,” said Dr. Nizar Madani, a surgeon who left Ghouta this week for Idlib. “And then it took another 24 hours until we arrived. It was exhausting.”
Some displaced residents and activists live-streamed parts of the journey north through lush fields and towns that appeared largely unscathed from the war.
In the Ghouta town of Arbeen, Dr. Bassam Bakri had been waiting for days with his wife and children for seats on the departing buses.
Dr. Bakri was in touch with those who have made it safely to Idlib, hearing stories of the difficult journey ahead of them. But he is focused on having to rebuild a new life, away from the destruction wrought upon his home.
“I’m just tired,” he said. “My wife, my mother and my daughters also need some rest like me.”
